review.title: Learning Compatibility Across Categories for Heterogeneous Item Recommendation
review.abstract: Identifying relationships between items is a key task of an online recommender system, in order to help users discover items that are functionally complementary or visually compatible. In domains like clothing recommendation, this task is particularly challenging since a successful system should be capable of handling a large corpus of items, a huge amount of relationships among them, as well as the high-dimensional and semantically complicated features involved. Furthermore, the human notion of "compatibility" that we need to capture goes beyond mere similarity: For two items to be compatible---whether jeans and a t-shirt, or a laptop and a charger---they should be similar in some ways, but systematically different in others.

sections.heading: V. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we introduced Monomer, a method for modeling heterogeneous relationships for item-to-item recommendation tasks. We found that existing methods for item-to-item recommendations suffer from a few limitations in dealing with heterogeneous data, mainly due to their dependence on metricity or "nearest neighbor" type assumptions. To overcome these limitations, our method used "blends" of non-metric embeddings that allow us to loosen the identity and symmetry assumptions of existing metric methods. The proposed scalable approach generates diverse and cross-category recommendations that capture more complex relationships than mere visual similarity. We demonstrated quantitatively that monomer is accurate in linking tasks using common purchase and co-browsing dyads from Amazon, and qualitatively that it is capable of generating diverse recommendations that are consistent with a particular visual style.

metadata.abstractText: Identifying relationships between items is a key task of an online recommender system, in order to help users discover items that are functionally complementary or visually compatible. In domains like clothing recommendation, this task is particularly challenging since a successful system should be capable of handling a large corpus of items, a huge amount of relationships among them, as well as the high-dimensional and semantically complicated features involved. Furthermore, the human notion of “compatibility” to capture goes beyond mere similarity: For two items to be compatible—whether jeans and a t-shirt, or a laptop and a charger—they should be similar in some ways, but systematically different in others. In this paper we propose a novel method, Monomer, to learn complicated and heterogeneous relationships between items in product recommendation settings. Recently, scalable methods have been developed that address this task by learning similarity metrics on top of the content of the products involved. Here our method relaxes the metricity assumption inherent in previous work and models multiple localized notions of ‘relatedness,’ so as to uncover ways in which related items should be systematically similar, and systematically different. Quantitatively, we show that our system achieves state-ofthe-art performance on large-scale compatibility prediction tasks, especially in cases where there is substantial heterogeneity between related items. Qualitatively, we demonstrate that richer notions of compatibility can be learned that go beyond similarity, and that our model can make effective recommendations of heterogeneous content. Keywords-Recommender Systems; Visual Compatibility; Metric Learning
